turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Hokkaido Island.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The systems integration site.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Mmm.  Look closer.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: As each component was tested and shipped off to Texas a duplicate was maintained and assembled in Hokkaido -- for backup purposes, of course. We've been right behind you the entire time.  You see my problem:  I couldn't appear to control too large a percentage; my enemies wouldn't stand for it.  So I simply made sure the Japanese consortium received the systems integration contract.  Of course no one had to know the corporations involved were recently acquired, wholly-owned subsidiaries --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: -- of Hadden Industries.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why don't you come back with me?

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Can't.  Doctor's orders.  The low oxygen/zero gravity environment is the only thing keeping the cancer from eating me alive.  It's all right -- I like it here. Ever try sex in zero-G?

turns.speaker: JEAN-CLAUDE
turns.text: Very well.  Assume this is true. Assume they have only the best of intentions.  Suppose they decide to just step in and solve all our problems for us.  You have no objection to them so flagrantly intervening in human affairs?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: We've just lived through a century of incredible violence and self- destruction.  Do you call it 'interventionist' when you stop a toddler from walking in front of a truck?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'd say this is slightly different.

turns.speaker: JEAN-CLAUDE
turns.text: Perhaps.  But on the off-chance that it is a 'doomsday device' of some kind, I plan to be very far away from your lovely Texas when it is activated.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I thought you were here because you want to go.

turns.speaker: JEAN-CLAUDE
turns.text: I do.  More than anything.  But I am also a realist.  Soon this... what is your charming term -- ?  Dog and pony show will finally be over, and I will go home.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You're implying that the whole selection process is a sham?

turns.speaker: JEAN-CLAUDE
turns.text: I think it is your naivete I like best about you, Eleanor.  Oh, there'll be a worldwide protest, but we all knew it from the very beginning.  You Americans discovered the signal, you led the decryption effort.  The machine is being built on your home soil... Of course the passenger will be an American, chosen by Americans.  Anyway, it is what the whole world wants, no?  This is the big show. The sort you put on better than anyone.  It's good marketing.  It's good casting.  It's the American way.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: ... Drumlin said you're been down at Arecibo for the last year.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's beautiful but it does get a little lonely.  Sometimes I think the reason we build these things in such godforsaken places isn't to avoid excess radio traffic but because we're all such pathetic antisocial misfits... Speaking of which:  How're you getting on with the old man?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: He's an incredible prick but I never learned so much in my life.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's what they all say.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Ellie.  Arroway.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Peter Valerian.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Sounds like a Russian general.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yavol.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I read your paper on ETI's.  It's brilliant.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Keep it down, okay?  Drumlin thinks I'm enough of a flake as it is.  Look -- everyone here has their little fetishes.  Caven goes to topless bars, Vernon's got his carnivorous plants... mine just happens to be extraterrestrial intelligence.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What a coincidence.  It happens to be my fetish too.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: ... I'm just so sick of feeling defensive about the things I care about!  Or being lumped in with the lunatic fringe by people like Drumlin, when if they'd just put aside their preconceptions for two seconds and look at the facts...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: They can't.  I think it's against human nature to admit to that level of... insignificance; to not see yourself as basically the center of the universe.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's like the pre-Copernicans who swore the sun revolved around the Earth, or the Victorians at the end of the last century who concluded that all major discoveries had now been made.  I mean... try to imagine civilization a thousand years ahead of us -- then imagine trying to explain... I dunno, a microwave oven -- to someone even a hundred years ago -- I mean the basic concepts didn't exist...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: 'Any sufficiently advanced technology...'

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: '... is indistinguishable from magic.'

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: ... I keep telling myself okay, that's just the price, you have to do your time doing shitwork before you're allowed to get to the good stuff... but if I have to catalog one more quasar...  God, I've missed you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Any luck on the grant money?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Please.  Any chance of that died the day David Drumlin was appointed head of the N.S.F.  I have been in contact with a few other SETI people; we've been trying to find backing from private investors. I've even managed to scrounge a couple of hours of telescope time here and there...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I've examined over forty stars of roughly solar spectral type but so far nothing.  Still, we've barely started...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: ... We've been going after some of the big multi-nationals but without much luck; got a donation from a New York dowager... We've even been thinking about selling T-shirts.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Ellie... even if you do manage to raise the money, have you thought about what it would really mean to follow through on this?  I mean a college fetish is one thing, but we're talking about your career. You won't be publishing.  You won't be taken seriously... and you could spend your entire life looking and never find anything at all.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: If we lived at any previous time in human history we wouldn't even have the option of failing -- we'd have to wonder our whole lives, unable to do anything about it.  This time, right now, is unique in our history, in any civilization's history -- the moment of the acquisition of technology.  The moment when contact becomes possible.  We've already beaten incredible odds by being lucky enough to be alive now.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: How close are you to getting this funding put together?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's almost there.  The hardest part is getting someone to sell us the telescope time.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What if I said I could get Drumlin to agree to sell you time in New Mexico?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The V.L.A.?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thirty-one linked dishes.  You could search more sky there in a day than you could in a year here.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Peter -- if you can get him to do that for me he'd obviously do the same for you -- we could -- !

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Actually --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: We could be together again --

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: -- I'm moving to Washington.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Greenbank?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm going on staff at the N.S.F.  To work for Drumlin.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But what about your research -- ?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: This is a chance to be of enormous help to other people's research -- to have the power to be a real advocate where David's got blind spots --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But the work --

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: 'The work,' Jesus, Ellie, can't there just once be more to life than the work?  Okay, maybe that's the only way to get the recognition, win the prizes --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Please, you're just as ambitious as I am, more --

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Maybe that's the problem.  I want... a family, Ellie.  I want kids.  A townhouse on L street instead of still living like a college kid.  A real life.  Maybe that makes me a sellout but I don't care anymore. It's what I want.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And you think I don't want those things?  You think I don't stay up half the night wondering if I've made the right choice living half a world away from you, wondering if any of this is worth what I'm giving up for it everyday?  Let's get married.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Jesus --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Right now -- we'll drive down to Ramey and get the base chaplain to marry us.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Ellie --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm serious about this, Peter --

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Ellie -- I'm getting married.  Her name's Laura.  She came up to Owens Valley to do her post-doc about six months after you left.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You sonofabitch.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That is true.  But it's also true that if I really thought we wanted the same things, I'd follow you anywhere... but the truth is I don't think you want the company.  Be honest, El.  There's nowhere you'd rather be than sitting out at some remote corner of the world searching for the answers to the mysteries of the universe.  And call me crazy, but I just can't compete with that... I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Ellie.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's good to see you, Ellie.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You too.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Someone tell me this is really happening.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's really happening.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That you, Valerian?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Like it or not.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Like it.  Almost there.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Ellie -- are you okay?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm -- I'm fine.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thank God.  When we lost contact, I thought -- we thought... but you're okay.  We're still trying to determine the nature of the malfunction.  Did you notice anything at all that --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Wait -- hold on a minute --

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's all right, the important thing is you're safe --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Peter, what are you talking about? What malfunction?  What day is this?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What day?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: How long was I gone?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Peter... What is going on?  Has everyone gone completely insane?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's one way of putting it.  Kitz, the President, the I.S.C. have shut down all official communications; there've also been reports of riots flaring up across the U.S. and Europe.  Until we figure out what went wrong things may get rough, especially for you --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But the machine worked -- that's what I've been trying to tell everyone!  The tape -- it's all there, if they'd just look at...  ... the tape...

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: I agree with Mr. Rank that there are unavoidable religious implications here -- but I don't think it justifies taking an alarmist position.  Dr. Arroway is right -- their chosen means of communication was a scientific one, and a scientific approach is probably appropriate, at least until the theological dimensions of the problem become more apparent.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And where exactly does that put your position...?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: I'd have to say I don't know enough to have one yet.  For the moment I don't believe the two approaches have to be mutually exclusive.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Champagne please.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Make that two.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: ... What I'm curious about are the wilderness years.  You're out there all alone, no money, mocked by the skeptics.  It must have taken tremendous faith.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'd say logic more than faith.  The odds were on my side.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: And what would you have done if the odds had gone against you?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I guess I would've felt sorry for the universe.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Spoken like a true believer.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What about you?  Doesn't all of this shake your faith at all?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: How do you mean?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well it's been a while, but I don't recall the Bible saying too much about alien civilizations.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: 'My father's house has many mansions.'

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Very smooth.  It's Palmer, right? Where I came from a palmer was a person who cheated at cards.  Really though... the Bible describes a God who watches over one tiny world a few thousand years old.  I look out there and see a universe of hundreds of billions of galaxies, each with hundreds of billions of stars... I mean burn me for a heretic, but your God seems awfully small.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Your 'faith' tells you that the distance a pendulum swings from the vertical can never get bigger, only smaller.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That's not faith, it's physics.  The second law of thermodynamics.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: And you believe this law with all your heart and soul.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And mind, yes.  What are you --

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: So if I let the pendulum go, when it swings back you wouldn't flinch.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I flinched.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Only a tiny bit.  Even the most devout believer is allowed a little doubt.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That's not doubt.  That's four hundred years of science fighting a billion years of instinct.  I always wondered what you religious types did with your free time.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Now you know.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: ... It's an old story.  I grew up in South Boston, more or less on the streets.  By the time I was thirteen I'd tried my first hit of heroin, by fifteen I'd stopped using but I was dealing full-time.  By the time I was nineteen I decided I didn't want to live any more, at least not in a world like that.  One day I got on a bus; I got as far as Ohio before my money ran out, and after that I just kept walking.  Didn't eat, didn't sleep... just walked.  I ended up collapsing in a wheat field.  There was a storm... I woke up...  And that's about as far as words'll go.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Can you try?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: I had... an experience.  Of belonging.  Of unconditional love. And for the first time in my life I wasn't terrified, and I wasn't alone.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And there's no chance you had this experience simply because some part of you needed to have it?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Look, I'm a reasonable person, and reasonably intelligent.  But this experience went beyond both.  For the first time I had to consider the possibility that intellect, as wonderful as it is, is not the only way of comprehending the universe. That it was too small and inadequate a tool to deal with what it was faced with.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You may not believe this... but there's a part of me that wants more than anything to believe in your God.  To believe that we're all here for a purpose, that all this... means something.  But it's because that part of me wants it so badly that I'm so stubborn about making sure it isn't just self-delusion. Of course I want to know God if there is one... but it has to be real.  Unless I have proof how can I be sure?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Do you love your parents?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I never knew my mother.  My father died when I was nine.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Did you love him?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes.  Very much.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Prove it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: So.  Is this kosher fraternizing with the enemy like this?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Some of my best friends are scientists.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I was referring to the selectees mingling with the selectors.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Some of my best friends are scientists.  They're saying the machine is alive.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Not exactly.  It has organic qualities, but we don't really understand how they're integrated with the mechanical systems.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Maybe you're creating a monster.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's too... elegant.  The degree of economy is extraordinary; it's really the next logical step... Even on Earth technology has always aspired to a condition of nature. D.N.A. outclasses any computer we can come up with; the human body is the most exquisitely designed machine imaginable.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: In other words, God is one hell of an engineer.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: In other words.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Relativity.  Explain this to me one more time... even if you traveled near the speed of light, when you came back --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: If you came back.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: If you came back... you'd only be four years older -- but over 50 years would have passed on Earth.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Something like that.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: And everybody you care about would be dead and buried.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: If you came back.  If you survived at all.  Which it's pretty certain you wouldn't.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: You're willing to die for this.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's what my whole life's been... aimed at; the only thing that's given it a sense of purpose.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I read your book.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Losing Faith:  The Search For Meaning In the Age of Reason. Catchy.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: What'd you think?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm more interested in the story behind the story... How a young man goes from living on the streets of South Boston to being the best- selling media figure rubbing elbows with the President.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: I won't deny I was ambitious.  When I had my... experience... I wanted to tell my story to as many people as possible.  I'm the first to admit that process included making some compromises.  You didn't answer my question.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I thought it was well-written. Heart-felt.  And a little bit naive... But that's just the enemy's perspective.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: I don't consider you the enemy, Ellie.  I'm not 'out to get' technology.  I only ask the question:  Does it have to have all the answers?  I look out there and I see so much emptiness... People are so starved for meaning, and it's something they just don't seem to be getting from science.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Did you ever stop to think that maybe that isn't science's fault, but meaning's?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: I don't follow.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Maybe the reason people are having trouble finding meaning isn't because science has obscured it... maybe it's just revealed it isn't there.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Do you really believe your life is meaningless?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't know.  But as a scientist I have to consider that possibility.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: And yet you're willing to die for this cause, the one thing that's given your life a sense of purpose. Don't you see the contradiction here -- ?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's getting late...

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: What are you so afraid of, Ellie?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Ellie --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's late.  We should go back.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: ... Another question I would ask would be a very simple one.  How did you do it?  How did you evolve as far as you have and not destroy yourselves?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: An excellent question, Doctor.  But what if we don't like the answer?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: How do you mean?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: What if their answer is, 'Oh, that's easy.  A thousand years ago our world was in terrible shape, our population out of control, violent crime, no food... so we called a general council and decided to eliminate the anit-social.  The weak.  The sick.  The unwanted.  And ever since we've been doing great.'

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Ellie... the last time we spoke... I said some things...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I remember.  You were indelicate, indiscreet and entirely less than tactful... Sound like anyone you know?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: So.  The final countdown.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The final countdown.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Oh.  I brought you something.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: During the crusades -- pilgrims who made the journey to the holy land brought back a palm frond to show they'd actually been there.  I thought it sort of made sense that Earth is now your holy land, so...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: You're trembling.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I do seem to be... Maybe because I'm just a little bit terrified about tomorrow.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Maybe that's okay.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: What...?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Ellie, what is it?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm sorry -- I can't --

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I can't do this --

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: What are you so afraid of?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Please, Palmer -- if you care for me at all, don't push this now --

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: What are my other options?  In fifty years?  Never?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Please --

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: I'm in love with you, Ellie.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Don't you understand?  I just have to hold it together -- just until tomorrow --

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: And then what?  Then you'll be safe?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: -- I don't know --

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Do you really think your life is meaningless, Eleanor?  Is that why you're so quick to risk it -- because if your life means nothing then you have nothing to lose?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I can't hear this now --

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Ellie, there is no reason you have to be alone.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And yet that's always how I seem to end up, isn't it?  If you really do love me, Palmer, you'll leave.  Now.  Please.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm assuming you read my deposition.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: It was quite a page turner.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Pretty ironic, huh?  I had to go all the way to the center of the galaxy... Just to find you.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: So.  I'm assuming they sent you here to administer last rites?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: I'm not sure it's come to that.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: They don't believe me.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You're sure you want to?  In the universe I saw we're not exactly the stars of the show.  What happened to me makes us all seem pretty damn small.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: It also makes God enormous.  I think of the scope of your universe, Ellie... and it takes my breath away.  As it will everyone else's.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't have any proof, Palmer.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Ellie, you're the proof.  You tell them your story.  Ultimately they'll have no choice but to believe you.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's not enough, don't you understand?  I know it happened -- but by every standard of science, by every standard I've lived my life by that fact is utterly beside the point.  It may be true but it doesn't matter because I can't prove it's real.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Ellie, the only one holding you to that standard is you!  The people want to hear your story, they need to hear it!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But --

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Have you seen what's happening out there?  The terror, the despair? The world is on fire, Ellie.  People need something they can believe in, something worthy, and you can give it to them!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I want to, Palmer -- more than anything.  But it has to be real. It has to be true.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Ellie... if you go out there like this -- if you admit to even the possibility that what you experienced didn't actually happen -- I'm afraid they really will crucify you.  Please.  For your own sake, for the sake of the world... tell them what you know to be the truth.  Tell them it really happened.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: ... but it is a good question, and I suppose I'll always wonder about the answer:  Why would they send me back without proof?

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Maybe what you experienced can't be reduced to images on a videotape. Maybe they still plan to grant your request, only in their own way, in their own time... Or maybe it's just like you said:  ultimately their motives may be as incomprehensible as their technology.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: In other words, God works in mysterious ways...

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: In other words.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't know.  If it was a god, it was searching for a greater one.  It was still searching for meaning...

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Does that mean you think it doesn't exist?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm not sure...  Maybe it simply exists in the search for it.  Maybe its something we have to make for ourselves.

turns.speaker: JOSS
turns.text: Meaning...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Something my dad -- they -- said. 'After all the suffering, after all the desolation of the void -- the one thing that makes the vastness tolerable is each other.'  The one thing that makes it bearable is love.

turns.speaker: PROJECT OFFICIAL
turns.text: You have a question, Dr. Arroway?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I question the thinking behind sending the first ambassador to another civilization in armed -- basically announcing our intentions are hostile.

turns.speaker: PROJECT OFFICIAL
turns.text: It's designed purely as a defensive device.  Call it a reasonable precaution.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Call it xenophobic paranoia.  Don't you see the absolute absurdity of this?  This isn't about them, it's about us -- our violence, our fear and mistrust --

turns.speaker: PROJECT OFFICIAL
turns.text: Dr. Arroway, you are entitled to your opinion.  But we feel quite strongly that it would by both irresponsible and naive to send a human being into a completely unknown, completely uncontrollable situation absolutely defenseless.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Y'know what?  Fine.  I guess if we want them to know the truth about who we are there's no quicker way to show them.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You kill me, you really do.  The first truly global, a-political event in history and you can't wait to spin it.

turns.speaker: PROJECT OFFICIAL
turns.text: How would you propose we handle it, Doctor?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I guess I'd say I trust us enough to believe our response would be something to the effect of, thanks for the advice, but no thanks.  But to dilute or censor the truth, for whatever reason --

turns.speaker: PROJECT OFFICIAL
turns.text: Nobody is proposing we censor the truth here, Doctor.  We're simply talking about putting a mechanism in place --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: For managing the truth.  But the truth won't be managed, sir.  It stops being the truth the moment you try.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT LASKER
turns.text: Oh my God...

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT LASKER
turns.text: Well.  That would seem to decide it. Like it or not, for the moment, anyway, it looks like we're all in this together.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: But --

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT LASKER
turns.text: That's it, Mike.  Last time I checked, I was still running the country.  Although it seems that for the moment, Dr. Arroway is running the planet.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: ... as have all attempts at internal analysis.  We've tried sonargrams, magnetic resonance, gamma rays; it's completely impenetrable.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT LASKER
turns.text: Recommendations?

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: I don't know.  Maybe we built the damn thing wrong.  Maybe it was all a hoax...  The safest thing would probably be to do a Chernobyl; encase it in concrete.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT LASKER
turns.text: Have your department make a full report.

turns.speaker: ALIBI
turns.text: Boss, I made an arrangement with that man to take his broom.

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: Git your shovel and git to work.

turns.speaker: ALIBI
turns.text: I don't think you understand. We made a deal ---

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: Git movin', I said.

turns.speaker: ALIBI
turns.text: But I made this arrangement --

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: Cut that backsass!

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: You don't take another man's place, boy.

turns.speaker: ALIBI
turns.text: It wasn't his fault. Nobody said anything about seats. We --

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: I'm lucky I got a broom. Work up top. Real easy job. Man, it's gonna be hot down in that ditch.

turns.speaker: ALIBI
turns.text: We work down in the ditch?

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Fifty cents? Sweet job like that worth at least a buck.

turns.speaker: ALIBI
turns.text: I'll make it a dollar.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Buck is a deal.

turns.speaker: ALIBI
turns.text: I've got this weak heart. Too much drinking, I guess. As soon as they find out about it, they'll probably send me someplace else.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Hot damn, Drag. Tomorrow's Saturday. Another week almost made.

turns.speaker: ALIBI
turns.text: I got two years.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: How'd you find me?

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: Helen, she sent along your things with a note, and John here, he wrote to the police.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah. Well.  Gettin' up here, Boss.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Well, Arletta, I got to stand down here.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: I allus hoped to see you well fixed and have me a crop of grandkids to kiss and fuss around with.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Like to oblige you, Arletta, but right off I don't know where to put my hands on 'em.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: Sometimes I wisht people was like dogs, Luke. Comes a time, a day like, when the bitch just don't recognize her pups no more, so she don't have no hopes nor love to bring her pain. She just don't give a damn. They let you smoke?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Smokin' it up here, Boss.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah, well, Arletta, you done your best. What I done with myself is my problem.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: No it hain't, Luke. You ain't alone. Ever whar you go, I'm with you, and so's John.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: You never thought that's a heavy load?

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: We allus thought you was strong enough to carry it. Was we wrong?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: No. But things ain't always like they seem, Arletta. You know that. A man's gotta go his own way.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: Well, I don't know, I just wash my hands of it, I guess I just got to love you and let go.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: What are you doin' here?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: We call it abuildin' time, Arletta.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: I ain't askin' what you'll do after you get out, because I'm gonna be dead and it don't matter.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: You never wanted to live forever anyways, did you? It wasn't such a hell of a life.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: Oh, I had me some high old times. Yore old man, Luke, wasn't much for stickin' around, but damn it he made me laugh.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah, would of been nice to of knowed him, the way you talk about him.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: You think life is some kind of ocean voyage and you start out with buntin' and hollerin' and high hopes, but the damn ship goes down before you ever reach the other side. Luke?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Here, Mom.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: What went wrong?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Nothin'. Ever'thing's cool's can be.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Tried to live always just as free and aboveboard as you been, and well, they ain't that much elbow room.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: You allus had good jobs, and that girl in Kentucky I taken a shine to her.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: She took off with that convertible feller...

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: Well, why not? Idee of marryin' got you all choked up, trying to pretend you was respectable you was borin' the hell out of all of us.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: I'm leavin' the place to John.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: That's good: he earned it.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: Nothin' to do with it. I ain't never give John the kind of feelin' I give you, so I'm payin' him off now. Don't feel you got to say anything. Way it is, sometimes, you just have a feelin' for a child or you don't, and with John I just didn't.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Gotta go, Arletta.

turns.speaker: ARLETTA
turns.text: Laugh it up, kid. You'll make out.

turns.speaker: BLIND DICK
turns.text: Lookit her bounce.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: Oh lean over here, lady. Lean this way.

turns.speaker: BLIND DICK
turns.text: Gotta have kings.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: Sure he's got kings but you still gotta call him.

turns.speaker: BLIND DICK
turns.text: Go hard!

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: Ram it in and break it off!

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: Tell us about it.

turns.speaker: BLIND DICK
turns.text: You steal a car?

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: A salesman! Cool Hand Luke a salesman?

turns.speaker: BLIND DICK
turns.text: He's probably a gigolo.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: We saw the broads.

turns.speaker: BLIND DICK
turns.text: Yeah. Did you have them both at once or --

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Comin' out here, Boss?

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: Yeah. Come on out, Luke.

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: You was eyeballin', Luke. You can't gitcha mind on them weeds if yer eyeballin'...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Boss, you don't need reasons to hit me.

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: Then how come it ain't done yet?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I don't know, Boss.

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: You don't know!

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: What's all this dirt in the yard?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Please! Please!

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: Git to work!

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Don't hit me! Please, for God's sake, don't hit me.

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: You got your mind right, Luke?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yes, Boss. I got it right.

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: Supposin' you was to backslide on us, Luke? Supposin' you was to backsass or try to run again...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: No, Boss! I won't. I won't. I got my mind right. I got it right, Boss. Please don't hit me no more.

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: Luke, you run again and we'll kill you.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I know, I know. Just don't hit me.

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: Go git it, Luke.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yes sir, Boss Paul!

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: You cut that up fer lunch, Luke.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yes, Boss.

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: He ain't even got the sense to run from the road like everybody else.

turns.speaker: DOGBOY
turns.text: Blue'll git him, Boss. We'll git that bastid, Cool Hand Luke.

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: Captain says to wait 'til the Patrol gits here.

turns.speaker: DOGBOY
turns.text: She's on to him. You shoulda waited fer me to git her out -- loose like she is, he kin run her crazy.

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: It ain't my fault you don't know how to handle your dogs.

turns.speaker: DOGBOY
turns.text: How my suppose to handle a dog someone jus' let loose?

turns.speaker: BOSS PAUL
turns.text: Here's the Patrol.

turns.speaker: DOGBOY
turns.text: She's got him! You hear that?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Here, Captain.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Maliciously destroyin' municipal property while under the influence. What was that?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Cuttin' the heads off parkin' meters, Captain.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Well, we ain't never had one of them. Where'd you think that was gonna get you?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I guess you could say I wasn't thinkin', Captain.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Says here you done real good in the war: Silver Star, Bronze Star, couple Purple Hearts. Sergeant! Little time in stockades. Come out the same way you went in: Buck Private.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: That's right, Captain. Just passin' the time.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Well, you got yourself some time now. Two years. Hell, that ain't much, we got coupla men here doin' twenty spots. We got one who's got all of it. We got all kinds and you gonna fit in real good. Course in case you git rabbit in your blood and decide to take off fer home, you git a bonus a some time and couple leg chains to keep you slowed down a little -- fer your own good. You'll learn the rules. It's all up to you. I can be a good guy or I can be one mean son-of-a-bitch, it's up to you.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: You gonna get used to wearing them chains aftera while, Luke. But don't you never stop listenin' to them clinkin'. That's gonna remind you of what I been sayin'.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah, they sure do make a lot of cold, hard, noise, Captain.

turns.speaker: TATTOO
turns.text: In the Navy, we used to call guys --

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Fasten your flap! All you Newmeats gonna have to shape up fast and hard on this gang. We got rules here an' in order to learn them, you gotta keep your ears open and your mouths shut.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: You was to sell your job, maybe this Lucas War Hero would give you a price.

turns.speaker: TATTOO
turns.text: I'll give you fifty cents.

turns.speaker: TATTOO
turns.text: Had it done in Singapore. Bunch of us drunk as coots --

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Hey, Tattoo!

turns.speaker: TATTOO
turns.text: -- went down to see this old hag and she had needles the size of that cane.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Only two? Man, I already done eight. Nothin' to it. Just make the days and let the weeks and the years make themselves.

turns.speaker: TATTOO
turns.text: I did three hitches in the Navy. It ain't bad. After a while, you get used to it and the time --

turns.speaker: TATTOO
turns.text: That ain't nuthing compared to what we used to do in San Pedro. There was this ensign...

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Ah believe I smell me a blonde-haired lady.

turns.speaker: TATTOO
turns.text: You can't do that!

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: You jes' watch us!

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Borrowin' or payin' back?

turns.speaker: TATTOO
turns.text: Borrowin'.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Mister Cool Hand here is the soft heart in our Loan Department. Next!

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: You gotta mind your manners, you actin' like a hillbilly tramp.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Tramp! Beautiful!

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Newmeat looks like a poker player, Drag.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Wouldn't surprise me none.  Wicker Man says you got a hundred- twenny and some change in the Captain's safe and you got your five dollars pocket money... That'll buy you a whole fistfull of cards. You in or out?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: She looks just like Mrs. Patricia Handy, a married woman... I useta fool with. Man, I kin sniff blondes from a hunnert yards and redheads from a mile and a half.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Drag's been chain-ganging so long he's got a nose like a bloodhound.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Oh, man, did you see her? Did you see her?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: I got eyes, don't I? How my not gonna see something like that?

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: I'm dyin'. I'm dyin'!

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Look, she's got paint on her toenails! Oh Lord, whatever I done, don't strike me blind for 'nother couple minutes. Oh you Lucille!

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Whatcha got?

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Pair'a nines.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: I kin see that, brick head. I mean your hole card.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Uh-huh. And he ain't got nothing showing. Raise his head off.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: He's been betting his head from the gun. Gotta have kings.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: So then you just call him.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: I call.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: But there's still daylight left.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: 'Bout two hours left.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Jus' take it slow, buddy.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: What happened? How far did you get?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Shut up. Let him eat. Don't pay them no mind, boy.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: He ain't eating beans fer lunch.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: He's eatin' steak and corn with butter and green beans and...

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Looka that! Two of them. Oh my...

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: I'm dyin'. I'm dyin'.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Lemme see it!

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Get away!

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Oh lookit that brunette.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Mah baby! We're diggin' and dyin' but our boy Luke is lovin' and flyin'.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Dragline, lemme look at the picture.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: What for?
